awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Engineering Design Instruction Software for implementing Objectives of Next (EDISON) Generation Standards in K-12
awd_abstract_narration:
This STTR Phase I project, the Engineering Design Instruction Software for implementing Objectives of Next generation standards, will combine Science Technology Engineering and Math (or STEM) concepts together with engineering design, simulation, 3-D printing, and gaming.  When finished the project will produce a virtual workspace for K-12 engineering design-test-build  projects, where elementary and middle level students can create concepts, build models, simulate and analyze, and fabricate designs for several types of projects like  bridges, CO2 cars, rockets, and robots.  This STTR project will offer positive exposure to STEM in the early and middle grades, when many students lose interest in these economically vital fields. Leveraging gamification, team collaboration, and 3D printing, this project provides an enriching engineering design experience that connects STEM content to real world applications. In making these real-world connections through engineering this project seeks to improve student academic performance in traditional science and math subjects. These features of this project are also designed to motivate and actively engage underrepresented students who may otherwise be reluctant to enter STEM fields. This work has the potential to promote more widespread integration of engineering in K-12 and better prepare students for future careers in STEM
 
 
This SBIR Phase I project  will produce  a collaborative workspace software that will use realistic design tools to support upper elementary and middle level students to create concepts, build models, simulate and analyze, export files for physical prototyping (3-D printing, cutting, or machining), and integrate with testing. Through these base of operations, this project will provide what other engineering curricula cannot - powerful tools for student evaluation, instructional assistance, and performance tracking. This project will apply real engineering tools to supports common challenges that appear in engineering curricula (for example, bridges, CO2 cars, and robotics).  Using the commercially available engines, user experience frameworks, and custom engineering tools, the team will create a gamified design environment with parametric geometry creation, modeling, analysis synthesis, simulation and multi-player collaboration capabilities. In Phase I, the project will be used and evaluated within several 5th-6th grade classrooms and a week long summer camp.  Supporting curricular materials will be developed in collaboration with our STTR partner institution.  The goal at the end of this project is the release of baseline product for commercialization that contains two different design project modules complete with software, curricular support materials, and evaluation data.

Project Outcomes:

This STTR Phase I project involved the development of EDISON, a game-based collaborative STEM workspace that uses realistic engineering design tools to support middle school students in learning and applying engineering. In EDISON students create concepts, build models, simulate and analyze, and test (3-D printing, cutting, or machining). In Phase I, our team investigated and demonstrated the technical feasibility and foundational features of EDISON.  The primary goal of the Phase I work was to develop a prototype beta release that will be used to assess potential commercial feasibility of EDISON.  This release has the core functionality and a limited set of educational modules. 

The next generation science standards (NGSS) propose the integration of engineering into science education and giving the design method equivalent treatment to scientific inquiry. Early exposure to engineering is a natural way to link the more traditional math and science disciplines and can improve student performance in the physical sciences, technology, and mathematics.  Most states have adopted or adapted these NGSS standards, but there is limited software, curricula, educational materials, and teacher training programs to help STEM educators integrate engineering in a more universal way especially at the middle school level.  Engineering concepts are usually difficult to integrate and explain without connecting them to a real-life design project.  Such projects can often require specialized equipment, costly materials, and significant instructor knowledge.  Furthermore, there are significant time constraints that make the integration of engineering into the traditional core challenging.  This presents a need for software and educational materials that can quickly add an engineering component in support of traditional STEM concepts.

 

EDISON addresses this need and is equal parts STEM curricula, engineering design and simulation platform, and constructivist game.  Students carry out virtual missions designing hobby scale projects to assist their game character. In doing so they apply engineering design, model problems using math and science, simulate their creations, and iterate on their designs before either exporting them (3-D printer, paper, etc.) for real world construction and testing. Commercial grade modeling, analysis, and simulation tools are fully integrated into the game. 

 

The approach for EDISON consists of four points: 1) Address middle school engineering instruction and standards for all students; 2) Utilize engineering as a multidisciplinary tool for targeting math, science, and literacy standards; 3) Provide a collaborative environment that fosters communication and contribution; and 4) Minimize the impact of implementation on: instruction time (using virtual design tools), preparation time (with embedded evaluation tools, game-based learning, scaffolded instruction, and integrated tutorial content), and on PD time by keeping the interfaces, strategies, and environments of the platform the same from one design module (For instance bridges) to the next (Ex. Cars). 

The broader impact and commercial potential of this project is an engineering education platform that fills a niche for middle school. There are many planned avenues for initial commercialization, including sales to schools, camps, and afterschool programs.  Future commercial opportunities will include stand-alone design-based games, design environments for hobbyists, and supporting kits. Engineering design promotes connections to practical applications could also improve student performance in the sciences, technology, and mathematics. If successful, EDISON would be an excellent way to inspire students to consider careers in the sciences and engineering at formative years in their education.

 

The following are key Phase I outcomes:

1)     The creation and implementation of the frameworks & tools for an engineering workspace allowing: problem formulation, concept generation, modeling, analysis, simulation, collaboration, prototyping, and data analysis

2)     The creation of curricula for two engineering design projects (bridges and cars) utilizing EDISON

3)     The creation of data driven tools for student evaluation and a dashboard utility for teachers to control content, manage users, and evaluate performance.

4)     The continuous engagement with end users and customers, and assessment of the prototype as tool for engineering instruction both for use by educators and youth.

5)     The development of relationships for partnership, distribution, marketing, and sales, including the initiation of district wide commercial pilots.

6)     Commercial pilot (before curricular purchase) featuring a limited but refined version of the Phase I demonstration prototype (in Sept. 2017).

Phase II efforts will broaden EDISON’s appeal and add value for the end user. This involves greater coverage of middle school math and science curricula and additional design module choices (rockets, robotics, etc.). The game will be refined including the art, UX, multiplayer, and customization tools.  Additionally, instructor tools for content creation and challenge authoring will be developed to allow 3rd party authoring of content for EDISON. Significant effort will also be expended in development to support our commercialization and partnership initiatives. Finally, new capabilities will support sensors, programming, and Mixed Reality on the platform.

 

Research Products:

Our product is the EDSION engineering platform prototype.
